summary.seg: The principal contents of this manuscript are the writings of the English surgeon John Arderne (1307/08-c. 1380). He wrote in Latin and the writings seem to date from c. 1370 to 1376. Four separate Middle English translations of his works made in the 15th century are also extant but Latin manuscripts are more commonly found (more than 40) before 1500, making Arderne one of the most popular medieval medical authors in England (see Cambridge, Gonville and Caius MS 190/223, ff. 7r-, for another Arderne manuscript). Arderne's writings usually take up the greater part of these Latin manuscripts, although not always in the same order. The best known of his works is the Practica of fistula in ano, a treatise on different forms of operation to treat fistulae and similar ailments affecting the backside and male genitals. In Trinity MS O.2.49 this work is found on ff. 35r-59r. Another identifiable Arderne text is called Extracta emoroidarum ('Extracts on haemorrhoids', drawn from authors and texts listed at the start), and in this manuscript the text runs from f. 63r to f. 73r. Other texts are harder to identify clearly, though there are extended passages on administering enemas, on eye diseases, and on ailments of the womb, for example. It has been convenient since the early 20th-century studies of D'Arcy Power to characterise these as belonging to a Liber medicinarum sive receptorum liber medicinalium ('Book of medicines or book of medical recipes'), though this is not a title found in Arderne's writings. Power's title does convey that most of what is found on ff. 1r-35r, 59r-63r, and 73r-82r consists of the medicinal virtues of herbs, compound medicines and recipes for a variety of ailments, not all of them surgical. Many other recipes of the same kind are also to be found in the Practica and in the Extracta emoroidarum.

There are charms and rituals interspersed with Arderne's recipes, as for example on f. 1r, where an experimentum to stop the flow of blood is a ritual using a split hazel rod. Some recipes, probably not authored by Arderne, are written in Middle English (see f. 1r again). Case histories of treatment are found scattered amongst Arderne's recipes and sometimes his patients are named (particularly in the Practica). Arderne manuscripts are usually accompanied by a programme of images in the margins of the text and this is true of Trinity MS O.2.49. In some deluxe manuscripts these are illuminated, but not here, where the images are hand drawn by the scribe. The subjects include herbs, injuries, bandages and instruments, and these images are often referred to by Arderne within the text. There are also diagrams of winds and humours, and a crude Zodiac Man preceded by a table of lunar days and zodiac signs. These are inserted within the text (on ff. 1r, 66r, 43v-44r respectively). There are also larger pictures of instruments and stages of the operation for fistula in ano (f. 40r-40v).

The other principal text in Trinity MS O.2.49 is anonymous and is titled Salus pauperum infirmorum vel adiutorium salutis ('Health of the sick poor or aid to health'). It begins with a liturgical prayer invoking God who has given medicine for men's help, and proceeds with recipes for ailments of the body from the head downwards. It ends with remedies for wounds of the limbs. On f. 97r there is a charm for spasm requiring names to be written on parchment and hung about the neck. The same charm is found in Arderne and the Salus pauperum has many remedies that might easily have come from his writings. Following the Salus pauperum are miscellaneous remedies including several for pestilence. On f. 99r-99v, there is a brief text by Walter Agilon, De pulsibus ('On pulses'), copied by the same scribe as before, who ends his text with 'Explicit de pulsibus quod Grene 1451'. In or about 1451 is therefore likely to be the date for the entire manuscript up to this point, and Grene seems to have been the main scribe. At the end of the manuscript is an incomplete and disordered index to the remedies in the text in a 17th-century hand.

On the flyleaves preceding the Arderne writings are various recipes, notes and diagrams, which were added to the manuscript by owners later in the 15th or early 16th centuries. Some are in English. On f. [ii recto], there are instructions for masses and almsgiving during a week for a soul in Purgatory by pseudo-Bernard of Clairvaux, followed by a later charm for cramp. On fol. [iii verso] there is a branching diagram in Latin differentiating kinds of disease, beginning with those affecting the whole body and ending with those affecting distinct parts of the body.

Peter Murray Jones
Fellow of King's College, Cambridge

listBibl.bibl: P.M. Jones, 'John of Arderne and the Mediterranean tradition of scholastic surgery', in Practical medicine from Salerno to the Black Death, ed. by L. Garcia-Ballester, R. French, J. Arrizabalaga and A. Cunningham (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1994), pp. 289-321
D'A. Power, Treatises of fistula in ono, haemorrhoids and clysters by John Arderne, Early English Text Society, o.s. 139 (London: Kegan Paul, Trench, TrÃ¼bner, 1910)

msItem.title: Account notes
msItem.incipit: [i] recto Item I payede for ij wel[.]es at Ã¾e furst
msItem.explicit: [i] recto bade for to by a linen clothe for [...] shyves and ijd for wyn and jd for [...]
msItem.note: Added in the late 15th or early 16th century.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: The second recipe is for treating St Anthony's Fire (antonys fyer), also known as ergotism.
Added in the late 15th or early 16th century.

msItem.title: Instructions for masses and almsgiving during a week for a soul in Purgatory
msItem.author: Pseudo-Bernard of Clairvaux
msItem.incipit: [ii] recto Seynt Bernard seyÃ¾e who so woll do in Ã¾[is] [faded] a soule passid ought of Ã¾is worlde yf he be in purgetor[y] he schall sone be delyueryd
msItem.explicit: [ii] recto Summa masses .vij. Summa of candill[es] .xlj. Summa of porefolke .xlj. Summa of pens iiij s etcaetera

msItem.title: Charm against cramp
msItem.textLang: Latin charm with Middle English heading
msItem.incipit: [ii] recto Anabal + abacule + cuth + tebuth _ Anahe + In nomine patris + et filij + spirituas + sancti Amen
msItem.note: Full transcription; added in the 15th century.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: The first recipe for treating gout requires the ingredients red nettles, brimstone and turpentine to be placed in the belly of a dehaired and disembowelled puppy (a younge whellpe), which is then roasted. The renderings from this are collected and the grease applied to the affected area. Other remedies are for colic, swelling of the 'coddes' and the stone.

msItem.title: Memorandum
msItem.incipit: [iii] recto Ro[bert] John Rychardes dwellyng yn [...] [?M]artyn [...].
msItem.note: Full transcription attempted; added by the same hand that added the account notes to f. [iii] recto.

msItem.title: Medical diagrams
msItem.note: Copied in the 15th century. The branching diagrams begins with the titles: Ad omnes partes corporis, de (?)feda ciones(?) per humores adustos, Ad quisdam partes corporis.

msItem.title: Liber receptorum medicinalium
msItem.author: John Arderne
msItem.incipit: 1r Ad Cancrum in virga virili siue in alio loco
msItem.note: A large collection of medical recipes and charms.

msItem.title: Medical recipes for haemorrhoids
msItem.note: Added to the lower margin by a 15th-century hand. The first recipe has a Middle English rubric, but a Latin text; the second is all in Middle English.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for 'a frensy and madmen'
msItem.rubric: 66r For a frensy and madmen to hele hem anone
msItem.note: Added to the lower margin by a 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Medical treatment called 'the great salve' (I)
msItem.rubric: 82v Thise beth the herbes Ã¾at schal be gaderid for Ã¾e grete saue at Ã¾e begynnyng
msItem.incipit: 82v Auance egremoyne herbe jon pigle bugle bugle sanatife herb robert herbes watter wilde fiches sanicle Ã¾e grete dayse Ã¾e lyttal daysye pinprunelle medwort betoyne Ã¾e whyÈtte croise Ã¾e yolou croise archangel pollipodyy
msItem.explicit: 83r first at morne fastynge and at eue last and lay on Ã¾e sore a brode brere lef when Ã¾e wound is opun and Ã¾at is medicine prouyde

msItem.title: Medical treatment called 'the great salve' (II)
msItem.incipit: 83r Tak betoyne bugle sanicle pimpernelle millefoyle streberwise orpin sauge moushere ambrose tansey sothernwode herbe robert herb wauter egrimoyne plantayne solsicle auence madur consoude confir osmunde crop of Ã¾e red netul red cole red brere and of Ã¾e hemp ana
msItem.explicit: 83v lay a red wort lef on the wounde and vse Ã¾is medycyne first at morne and last at euen and beware lest he take to mekyl at onus let hit hele to swithe

msItem.title: Verses on herbal medicine against the plague from the Regimen sanitatis salernitanum
msItem.incipit: 83v Hec olus vrtica tribulus tenasia canabis que / has herbas circa baptiste collige festum
msItem.explicit: 83v hiis quoque temporibus oleris folio tege plagas / Nil appone maius habitis in corpore plagis

msItem.title: Recipe for making a medicinal water called Aqua Vitae
msItem.textLang: Middle English recipe with a Latin title
msItem.incipit: 84r Tak Ã¾e rote of saxifrage and persil alisaundur fenel tyme ysope piliole rale rosemarine lauandur primerose mynte origanum sauge calamynt auance betoyne and saueyne ana
msItem.explicit: 84r and let hem stande all a nyht and stepe and on Ã¾e morne distille in a serpentyne or in a lymbike

msItem.title: Tract on the virtues of Aqua Vitae
msItem.textLang: Middle English text with a Latin title
msItem.incipit: 84v Ãis water is goude and has many fayre virtues it helpus a bodi fro all colde maladies and whoso can vse hit kyndly it is a confortatiffe agayne all maner of malady
msItem.explicit: 84v and it be pourd in to Ã¾e heres leu it amendis stynkynge breÃ¾e and helus of Ã¾e fallynge euel it helpus a man of Ã¾e palesye

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: The collection contains a Middle English recipes for making clarre orpyment and bragot delicius and medicinabull.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for Aqua Vitae
msItem.incipit: 85v Aqua vite perfecta valet contra omnes infirmatiates cordis stomachi et capitis pulmonis latere et vesice valet contra paralisium et contra omnem frigidam materiam inter corpus
msItem.explicit: 85r et sic vices itera et in dubie sanabitur
msItem.note: The text is accompanied by two drawings of interconnected vessels illustrating chemical processes in the outer and lower margins of f. 85v.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: The collection includes a recipe for treating 'madness' or 'Insania' (ffor madnys a remedy y proued) on f. 87v. It also includes recipes for making red or green wax and musk for medicinal purposes on f. 88r.

msItem.title: Salus pauperum infirmorum (with medical recipes)
msItem.rubric: 89r Salus pauperum infirmorum vel adiutorium salutis
msItem.incipit: 89r Ad honorem dei et domini ihesu Christi et sue matris marie virginis dulcissime et [omnium] sanctorum et ad salutem pauperum infirmorum medicis cirurgie et quasdam phisice a multis doctoribus approbatur et a me licet indignum multociens die autoritate expertas vicissim collegi et hic breuiter secundum scienciam a domino medicum mihi datum compilaui
msItem.note: One recipe (f. 98v) explicitly refers to the treatise's title: Medicinam pro pauperibus sumatur omni ebdomada semel vel bis in quantitate nucis parue cum vino albo at aqua rosarum vel plantaginis.

msItem.title: Poem on weights and measures (6 lines)
msItem.explicit: 99v vncia pars librae duodena dicitur esse

msItem.title: Note on the importance of pulses for uroscopy
msItem.incipit: 99v visa urina oportet quod pulsus tangatur quod urine iudicium per pulse certificatur
msItem.explicit: 99v si pulsus et vrina consenserint tunc est iudicium certum et aliter non

msItem.title: Alphabetical index
msItem.note: An alphabetical index (A-V) of the medical recipes in the manuscript, added by a 17th-century hand. The leaves are now out of order, beginning D-E, E-F, A-B, C-C, G-H, etc.

supportDesc.support: Three parchment flyleaves, followed by a manuscript consisting of paper (ff. 1-99 is medieval and ff. 100-105 is early modern paper), folded in quarto. Folios 1-105: various watermarks but none identified.

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil at the centre (written next to the corresponding 16th-century foliation) of the upper margin of the recto of each leaf.
The unfoliated early modern flyleaves at the beginning and end have been allocated alphabetical letters between square brackets for reference purposes in this electronic catalogue record.

foliation.p: Written in dark brown ink at the centre of the upper margin of the recto of each leaf.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in dark ink written in the lower inner corners of the last versos of quires.

supportDesc.condition: Many of the leaves at the beginning and end of the original manuscript (ff. 1-99) have been damaged and repaired with modern blank paper.

layout.seg: Ruled in hardpoint, frame only. Mainly single columns (except ff. 99r-105v which have two columns). 33-40 lines to the page, written above top line.

handNote.p: ff. 1r-99v have been copied by one or two hands writing a cursive script with both anglicana and secretary features.

The notes and medical texts added to the manuscript's original flyleaves (ff. [i] recto-[iii] recto) have been copied by a variety of 15th- and 16th-century hands in various cursive scripts with anglicana and secretary features.
The text with an instruction for masses for souls in Purgatory on f. [ii] recto is written by a cursive hand with mostly secretary features.
The diagrammatic text on f. [ii] verso is written by a hand writing in a textualis script.

The notes and medical texts added to the manuscript's original flyleaves (ff. [i] recto-[iii] recto) have been copied by a variety of 15th- and 16th-century hands in various cursive scripts with anglicana and secretary features.
ff. 99r-105v have been copied by a single hand in a humanistic cursive script.

decoNote.p: Marginal, intra-textual and half-page drawings (ff. 40r-40v) of medical patients, ingredients, instruments in brown ink, but sometimes with wounds and blood highlighted in red ink.

A square diagram divided into four smaller squares in which the names of the winds are written and which are organised on the outside according to the four elements and cardinal directions, drawn in brown ink (f. 1r).
A simplified outline drawing of the Zodiac Man diagram, accompanied by labels (f. 44r).

A circular diagram divided into eight compartments by diametrical double lines with the names of astronomical events written inside them, drawn in brown ink. On the outside, it shows how the four humours govern each other during the year (f. 66r).

note.p: A (?)17th-century hand has added the title Tractatus Chyrurgicus a.d. 1451 to the manuscript on f. [i] recto.

binding.p: Modern 20th-century half brown leather binding with marbled paper sides; 5 raised bands on the spine.

origin.p: For date of production, see Robinson, Catalogue of dated and datable manuscripts in Cambridge libraries (1988), no. 370.

provenance.p: Thomas Gale (1635/6-1702) Gale, Thomas, 1635/6-1702, dean of York, antiquary and fellow of Trinity College Cambridge.
One of the manuscripts of Roger Gale (1672-1744) Gale, Roger, 1672-1744, antiquary and scholar, son of Thomas Gale. Inherited from his father.

history.acquisition: Donated to Trinity College by Roger Gale (1672-1744)Gale, Roger, 1672-1744, son of Thomas Gale (1635/6-1702), in 1738. The manuscript's old number and current classmarks inscribed on f. [i] recto: E.19., No 206 and O.2.49. The alpha-numerical elements of its current classmark are printed on three three labels pasted onto the spine (O.2.49), and those of its current and previous classmarks are inscribed in the manuscript: f. [i] recto (E.19 [crossed out] and O.2.49 in dark ink). Its printed ex libris featuring its armorial coat of arms and name (Collegium S.S. et Individuae Trinitatis in Academia Cantabrigiensis) pasted on f. [ii] verso. The college's library stamp can be found on ff. [i] recto, [iii] recto, and 105v.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M.R. James, The western manuscripts in the library of Trinity College, Cambridge: a descriptive catalogue, 3 (1902); and Linne R. Mooney, Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge The Index of Middle English Prose, Handlist XI (Woodbridge: Brewer, 1995).

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.
